review.title: Convergent message passing algorithms - a unifying view
review.abstract: Message-passing algorithms have emerged as powerful techniques for approximate inference in graphical models. When these algorithms converge, they can be shown to find local (or sometimes even global) optima of variational formulations to the inference problem. But many of the most popular algorithms are not guaranteed to converge. This has lead to recent interest in convergent message-passing algorithms. In this paper, we present a unified view of convergent message-passing algorithms. We present a simple derivation of an abstract algorithm, tree-consistency bound optimization (TCBO) that is provably convergent in both its sum and max product forms. We then show that many of the existing convergent algorithms are instances of our TCBO algorithm, and obtain novel convergent algorithms "for free" by exchanging maximizations and summations in existing algorithms. In particular, we show that Wainwright's non-convergent sum-product algorithm for tree based variational bounds, is actually convergent with the right update order for the case where trees are monotonic chains.

In this paper, we present a unified view of converged message passage algorithms. We present a simple derivation of an abstract algorithm, tree consistency related optimization (TCBO), which is demonstrably convergent in both its sum and maximum product forms. We then show that many of the existing converged algorithms are instances of our TCBO algorithm, and obtain new converged algorithms "free of charge" by replacing maximizations and sums in existing algorithms. Specifically, we show that wainwrights of non-converged sum product sequences are actually the right algorithms for tree convergence.

sections.heading: 7 Discussion
sections.text: Despite the empirical success of Max Product and Summary Product algorithms in applications, the convergence of original algorithms is not guaranteed. Therefore, much research in recent years has focused on the development of convergent algorithms. Typically, these newer algorithms are either Max Product or Summary Product, and their evidence of convergence is algorithmically specific. Here, we have also presented a unified framework for convergent messaging algorithms and demonstrated the importance of enforcing consistency in both sum products and maximum products. This analogy allows us to provide a unified derivative for existing algorithms, and it provides an easy way to derive new algorithms from existing ones by replacing maximizations and sums. Although many converged algorithms are instances of our framework, it is worth pointing out two converged algorithms that are not converged.
